text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute Englishâ€“ the show that brings you an interesting topic,
speaker: Dan

text: authentic listening practice and vocabulary to help you improve your language skills.
I'm Dan and I'm Neil. In this program we'll be discussing armed police,
as well as teaching you six new items of vocabulary, of course.
Can we get this done quickly today Neil? Only I've got to shoot off to a party later.
speaker: shoot off

text: Shoot off, meaning leave quickly, of course we can.
And it's funny you should mention shooting because our topic this week is gun control
without guns. Is that so? I have a question about that for you.
Fire away then. Fire away, an expression giving permission for someone to
speaker: Fire away

text: ask a question or speak. So which country has the oldest gun control laws in the world?
Is it A, the USA? B, Iceland or C, Japan?
I'm going to guess b) Iceland, just because I've never been there
speaker: Neil

text: Well we'll find out if you're right a bit later on.
Now, imagine the scene. You are a police officer who's been called out to deal with an incident.
When you arrive on scene you find a dangerous criminal. Do you reach for a gun or a blanket?
Okay it's got to be a gun. Well in most countries in the world you'd be right,
but not in Japan. Despite carrying guns, Japanese police almost never use them.
speaker: Neil

text: Instead they rely on a combination of martial arts and in many cases where a person is violent
they bring out the futon, which is a kind of blanket and they wrap them up and restrain them
or prevent them from moving. You're pulling my leg. Nope. Listen to Japanese journalist
Antony Berto describe the situation. What most Japanese police will do is to get huge
futons and essentially roll up the person who's being violent or drunk into a little burrito
and carry them back to the station and calm them down. The response to violence is never
speaker: Dan

text: violence. It's always to de-escalate it. So they safely restrain the person and wait for the
situation to de-escalate or become less intense. Unless a criminal has a gun, Japanese police
speaker: restrainde-escalate

text: never fire their weapons. Surely that means that the criminals always have the advantage then.
You'd think so, but no. It seems that guns don't really feature in crimes much in Japan
speaker: Neil

text: Well that's astonishing. So do you think the criminals don't carry guns because the police don't
speaker: Neil

text: carry guns or that the police don't carry guns because the criminals don't carry guns?
Well that makes my head hurt. Well I don't know, but listen to what Ian Overton, the executive
director of Action on Armed Violence, says about armed police in society.
The American model has been militarized the police, but the challenge I have is that there is
very little evidence that a more militarized police results in a more peaceful society.
And I'm very concerned that if you have too many police pulling out gun for the first
instance of crime, then you lead to a miniature arms race between police and criminals.
So America tends to militarize its police, meaning to equip them and use them as an army.
And that causes an arms race with the criminals, which is a competition between two groups
speaker: militarise

text: to have more weapons than the other group. He also said there's not a strong connection between
armed police and a peaceful society. So does that mean that Japanese society is more peaceful?
speaker: Neil

text: Well violent crime still happens there, but criminals tend to carry other weapons,
such as swords and knives. But at least it's a step in the right direction.
Now can you remember the quiz question I asked? I think so. You asked me which country has the
oldest gun control laws in the world? Is it A USA, B Iceland or C Japan? And I said B Iceland.
speaker: Neil

text: Well I'm sorry Neil, that's not right, but don't shoot the messenger, okay?
It's Japan, which implemented its gun control laws in 1685.
How interesting. Now, let's take a look at the vocabulary from this program
speaker: Neil

text: Sure. We had shoot off. If you shoot off, it means you leave somewhere in a hurry.
What type of verb is it Neil? Can you give us an example?
It's a phrasal verb so it's used conversationally and usually in an informal context.
speaker: he shot off to the hospitalfire away.  fire away

text: As for an example, when he heard his wife was sick, he shot off to the hospital.
Synonyms could be dash off or run off. Next we had fire away. Now fire away is an expression
giving permission for someone to ask a question or speak. Can you think of any other ways to say
the same thing, Dan? If I said can I ask you a question? I'd say yes, of course. Go ahead.
Please do or by all means. Restrain. If you restrain someone, you prevent them from moving.
In another sense, you might restrain yourself from doing something, for example eating chocolate.
Have you ever had to restrain your children for anything Neil?
I have to restrain my children all the time, Dan, otherwise they would fight like mad
speaker: restrainrestrainde-escalate de-escalates

text: I have to pull them apart and restrain them. Okay, deescalate. If something deescalates,
it becomes less intense. This is often used in the context of conflicts or argument.
Can you think of a historical example, Dan? Well, in the 1960s, the Cuban Missile Crisis
escalated over a period of two weeks and deescalated only after diplomatic negotiations were successful,
but it was pretty close to World War 3 at one point.
Militarize. If something is militarized, it is equipped and used like an army.
Give me an example of people who have become militarized, Neil.
Yes, when I was a student in the United Kingdom some of the foreign students had to go home
speaker: militarisedarms race.Â  arms race

text: to take part in national service. That's joined the army for a couple of years.
So they became militarized. Now, an arms race. An arms race is a competition between two groups
to gain more weapons than the other group. Got an example of that, Dan?
The most famous example of this is the Cold War. Both the USSR and the USA
speaker: arms race

text: became involved in an arms race to stockpile as many nuclear weapons as possible.
Well, that's the end of today's six minute English. Please join us again soon.
And we're on social media too, so make sure to visit us on Facebook, Twitter,
Instagram and YouTube. Goodbye. Bye-bye.
